column2: What are the two basic principles of operation fofr the B737 electrical syste,?
column3: No paralleling of AC sources. Connecting a source to a transfer bus automatically disconnects an existing source.

column2: What are the three main divisions of the B737 electrical power system?
column3: AC power system; DC power system; standby power system.

column2: Which buses does each AC power system consists of?
column3: Transfer bus (1);  Main bus (1); Galley buses (2); Ground Service Bus (1).

column2: Which AC transfer bus powers the AC standby bus under normal conditions?
column3: Transfer bus 1 supplies the AC standby bus.

column2: If the AC source powering an AC transfer bus fails or is disconnected, how can that transfer bus be powered?
column3: It can be powered by any available source through the tie bus via the bus tie breakers (BTBs).

column2: What does selecting GRD PWR Switch ON do on the ground with both generators off the bus?
column3: If ground power available: removes previously connected power from AC transfer buses; connects ground power to AC transfer buses if power quality is correct

column2: What does selecting either APU GEN switch to ON do to the AC transfer buses?
column3: If neither AC transfer bus powered by IDG: - Connects both AC transfer buses to APU generator; disconnected external power, illiminates oppposite SOURCE FF light until other APU GEN switch moved to ON. If both AC transfer buses powered by IDGs: - Powers the related transfer bus from the APU generator; - Other transfer bus continues to receive power from the IDG

column2: Can one AC transfer bus be powered by external power while the other is powered by the APU?
column3: No.

column2: GEN switch (ENG) — what does OFF do?
column3: Disconnects the IDG from the related AC transfer bus by opening the generator circuit breaker.

column2: GEN switch (ENG) — what does ON do (momentary)?
column3: Connects the IDG to the related AC transfer bus by disconnecting the previous power source and closing the generator circuit breaker.

column2: In flight, with one engine generator no longer supplying power and BUS TRANSFER in AUTO, what happens to the transfer buses?
column3: BTBs automatically close so the remaining generator can supply both transfer buses through the tie bus/BTBs.

column2: If the airplane takes off with the APU powering both transfer buses and the APU is shut down or fails, what happens? How many times can this occur?
column3: - Engine generators are automatically connected to their related AC transfer buses. - This occurs only once in flight and only in that circumstance.

column2: BUS TRANSFER switch — AUTO (guarded): what does it allow for AC and DC?
column3: AC: BTBs operate automatically to maintain power to AC transfer buses from any operating generator or external power. DC: DC cross tie relay automatically provides normal or isolated operation as required.

column2: BUS TRANSFER switch — OFF: what does it do (AC + DC + TR3 input)?
column3: AC: isolates AC transfer bus 1 from AC transfer bus 2 (if one IDG is supplying both). DC: DC cross tie relay opens to isolate DC bus 1 from DC bus 2. Also inhibits TR3 input from connecting to AC transfer bus 1.

column2: What is the order of load shedding during single generator operation?
column3: Sheds incrementally: (1) galleys and main bus on transfer bus 2; (2) galleys and main bus on transfer bus 1; (3) IFE buses.

column2: When source capacity returns to two-generator operation, what restores automatically and what requires CAB/UTIL reset?
column3: IFE/PASS buses restore automatically. Galley and main bus power require CAB/UTIL switch reset (OFF then ON) to restore.

column2: APU-only electrical power in flight: what is shed automatically (and what else if overload persists)?
column3: All galley buses and main buses are automatically shed. If load still exceeds limits, both IFE buses are also automatically shed.

column2: APU on the ground with overload sensed: what does the APU shed, and how can you attempt restoration?
column3: Sheds galley buses and main buses until load is within limits. Restoration can be attempted by moving CAB/UTIL switch OFF then back ON.

column2: DC power system: what supplies 28V DC power under normal conditions?
column3: Three transformer-rectifier (TR) units energized from the AC transfer buses supply 28V DC.

column2: TR units convert what to what?
column3: Convert 115V AC to 28V DC.

column2: Which AC transfer bus powers TR1 and TR2?
column3: TR1 receives AC power from transfer bus 1. TR2 receives AC power from transfer bus 2.

column2: TR3 normally receives AC power from which transfer bus, and what is its backup source (when BUS TRANSFER is AUTO)?
column3: Normally from transfer bus 2, with backup AC power from transfer bus 1.

column2: How many TRs are required to supply the total connected load?
column3: Any two TRs are capable of supplying the total connected load.

column2: Under normal conditions, how are DC bus 1, DC bus 2, and the DC standby buses powered? How are they connected to one another?
column3: .TR1 and TR2 each power DC bus 1, DC bus 2, and the DC standby bus. They are connected via the cross bus tie relay;
column5: Ch 6 §6.20.5 (DC buses / cross bus tie relay)

column2: Under normal conditions, what does TR3 power and what is its role?
column3: TR3 powers the battery bus and serves as a backup power source for TR1 and TR2.

column2: Under which two conditions does the cross bus tie relay open?
column3: At glideslope capture during a flight director or autopilot ILS approach; and when the BUS TRANSFER switch is positioned to OFF.
column5: Ch 6 §6.20.5 (Cross bus tie relay) + §6.10.4 (BUS TRANSFER OFF)

column2: TR UNIT light: when does it illuminate in flight vs on the ground?
column3: In flight: illuminates if: [TR1 OR  (TR2 AND TR3)]  has failed. On the ground: any TR fault causes the light to illuminate.

column2: ELEC light: what does it indicate on the ground and in-flight?
column3: On the ground: indicates a fault exists in the DC power system or standby power system. In flight: ELEC light is inhibited.

column2: What is the chemistry and nominal voltage of the battery? Where is it located?
column3: 24V nickel-cadmium battery;  located in the electronics compartment.

column2: How long is the fully-charged battery capable of providing standby power?
column3: Minimum of 30 minutes.

column2: What is the battery voltage range?
column3: 22–30 volts.

column2: After loss of both generators, which DC buses does the battery power?
column3: Battery bus; DC standby bus;Hot battery bus; Switched hot battery bus.

column2: When is the Switched Hot Battery Bus powered?
column3: Whenever the battery switch is ON.

column2: How is the Hot Battery Bus connected to the battery?
column3: Directly.

column2: What does the Standby Power System provide and when?
column3: Provides 115V AC and 24V DC power to essential systems in the event of loss of all engine or APU-driven AC power.

column2: What are the components (2) and buses (5) that comprise the Standby Power System
column3: Static inverter;  main battery.; AC standby bus; DC standby bus; battery bus; hot battery bus; switched hot battery bus.

column2: With both AC Transfer Buses powered by their generators and the guards down on the BAT and STANDBY POWER switches, what powers the following buses: AC Standby Bus; DC Standby Bus; Battery Bus; Hot Battery Bus; Switched Hot Battery Bus?
column3: In the Normal Standby Power System Configuration, what powers the following buses?  AC Standby Bus: AC Transfer Bus #1; DC Standby Bus: TR1, TR2, and TR3; Battery Bus: TR3; Hot Battery Bus: Battery and/or Battery Charger; Switched Hot Battery Bus: Battery and/or Battery Charger.

column2: With the loss of all AC generators and the guards down on the BATTERY  and STANDBY POWER switches, what powers the following buses: AC Standby Bus; DC Standby Bus; Battery Bus; Hot Battery Bus; Switched Hot Battery Bus?
column3: With the loss of all AC generators and the guards down on the BATTERY  and STANDBY POWER switches, what powers the following buses: AC Standby Bus: Battery via static inverter; DC Standby Bus: battery; Battery Bus: battery; Hot Battery Bus: battery; Switched Hot Battery Bus: battery?

column2: Standby power switch — AUTO: when does automatic switching from normal to alternate occur?
column3: If power from either AC transfer bus 1 or DC bus 1 is lost.

column2: Standby power switch — BAT: what does it do (and what happens if BAT switch is OFF)?
column3: Overrides automatic switching and places AC standby bus, DC standby bus, and battery bus on battery power. Battery switch may be ON or OFF; if battery switch is OFF, the switched hot battery bus is not powered.

column2: Standby power switch — OFF: what happens?
column3: De-energizes AC standby bus and DC standby bus and illuminates the STANDBY PWR OFF light.

column2: What does the Static Inverter do?
column3: Converts 24V DC from the battery to 115V AC to supply the AC standby bus during loss of normal electrical power.

column2: What controls the Static Inverter's power supply?
column3: The standby power switch and the battery switch on the overhead panel.

column2: What does the GROUND SERVICE do?
column3: Connects/disconnects external power to the ground service buses without activating AC transfer buses.

column2: What AC indications are provided on the AC/DC metering pane?
column3: Voltage, Current, and Frequency of the selected AC source.

column2: What DC indications are provided on the AC/DC metering pane?
column3: Voltage and Current of the selected DC source.

column2: What does the GRD POWER AVAILABLE light mean?
column3: Ground power is connected and meets airplane power quality standards.

column2: What does the OFF position of the GRD PWR switch do?
column3: Disconnects ground power from the AC transfer buses.

column2: What happens when the GRD PWR switch is  moved to ON (with ground power available)?
column3: Removes previously connected power from AC transfer buses, then connects ground power to the AC transfer buses (if power quality is correct).

column2: What does the TRANSFER BUS OFF light indicate?
column3: The related AC transfer bus is not powered.

column2: What does the SOURCE OFF light indicate?
column3: No source has been manually selected to power the related AC transfer bus, or the manually selected source has been disconnected.

column2: What does the GEN OFF BUS light indicaet"?
column3: IDG is not supplying power to the related AC transfer bus.
